Award.AwardTitle: Resource Allocation for Airliner Safety: A Design Perspective on Dealing with the Unexpected in Complex Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to model the contributions to airliner safety of processes used by aircraft builders, the airline industry and their regulators and to explore their impact on airliner structural design. This will allow an aircraft designer to present to a customer the choice between designing more safety into the airplane versus achieving the same level of safety though maintenance and training procedures. Inspired by a crash of an American Airlines airplane due to extreme rudder commands, the research will also explore a new approach for reducing unexpected failures by simulations of extreme behavior by a pilot. The research thus addresses a critical lack in the current design framework of complex systems by systematically uncovering processes of unexpected and un-modeled failure scenarios and by including operators? extreme behavior into the design and safety assessment.

If successful, the research will provide insight for aircraft builders, airlines, Congress and the President on strategies to improve safety at less cost, resulting in more efficient resource allocation at the national level. This can help decisions on directing resources to safety research, tax incentives to aircraft builders, maintenance and pilot training and regulations and accident investigations. Although the proposed research focuses on aircraft structures, the same frameworks can be applicable to any complex engineering system whose safety depends on a sequence of processes throughout its life cycle. This includes infrastructural systems, whose reliability is directly related to public safety. A Ph.D. student from an international joint Ph.D. degree program will enhance international collaboration, and an undergraduate student will be recruited for research from underrepresented groups. Two graduate and undergraduate courses will closely be integrated with this research. The research results will be widely distributed for maximum impact in a variety of conference and journal venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Airline safety is a very high priority to the public. One of the first issues dealt by the project was to assess how much, by comparing safety levels in terms of fatalities per billion passenger miles between different modes of transportation. Airlines were found to be about a 1,000 times safer than small general avaiation planes. However, these safer modes of transportation elicited much more regulations and expense of implementing them than the less safe modes of transportation. This led us to believe that the public demands much more safety when being transported by somebody else. Comparison of buses to private automobiles showed similar trend. If this interpretaton is correct it may mean that self driving cars will be held to a much higher safety requirements than cars driven by people.

In terms of design for safety, the two PhD students supported by the project chose to focus on two opposite ends of the design process. Garrett Waycaster focused on the interaction between aircraft builders and the airlines on the overall design of an airplane. In particular, the tradeoffs between fuel efficiency and cost of the airplanes for a given level of safety are difficult because the designer makes decisions on airplanes that will fly a decade or more later. Waycaster used game theory to model the relationship between airline builders (like Boeing and Airbus) and airlines (like Delta or British Air). He also analyzed data over two decades to try and deduce which market conditions have the highest impact on the profits of aircraft builders and airlines. Not surprisingly, the state of the economy, and fuel prices loomed large. On the way there he developed methodology that helps identify the best model to fit the data on airlines and aircraft builders in terms of airliner characteristics, revenues, profits, and safety.

The second PhD student, Kanwardeep Bhachu focused on resource allocation for safe structural design of aircraft wings by making them damage tolerant. He looked at the allocation of resources for testing material characteristics for carrying more weight of a stronger structure, and for quality control in manufacture to discover manufacturing errors that can lead to structural failure. He concluded that more material testing than is done today may allow us to build lighter and cheaper airplanes.

The two students benefitted from opportunities to intern and collaborate with others. Waycaster was directed by two professors at the University of Florida (Haftka and Kim), by a British Economics professor (Bilotkach) and by two French professors (Bes and Gogu). He spent four months in France and obtained a dual PhD degree from Florida and the Paul Sabatier University in Toulouse France.

Bhachu was directed by Haftka and Kim, and had strong interaction with the Cessna corporation where he spent two summer internships and published papers with Cessna personnel. He also had an internship at the General Electric Global Research Center in Niskayuna NY.
